subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{n(n+2)} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{2n}{3n+1} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{n(n+1)(n+2)} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(\\frac{1}{2^{n}}-\\frac{1}{3^{n}}) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{\\sqrt[n]{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{5^{n-1}+4^{n+1}}{3^{2n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(\\sqrt{n+2}-2\\sqrt{n+1}+\\sqrt{n}) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{2n-1}{3^{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence and divergence of the following series. If it converges, find the sum: \\( \\sum_{n=0}^{\\infty}q^{n}\\cos n\\theta \\quad (|q|<1) \\)
analysis: Using Euler formula: \\sum q^n e^{in\\theta}. S_n = \\frac{1}{1-qe^{i\\theta}}. [cite_start]\\\\ Real part: \\frac{1-q\\cos\\theta}{1-q^2-2q\\cos\\theta} [cite: 21-23]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{4n}{n^{4}+1} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{2n^{2}}{n^{3}+3n} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{\\ln^{2}n} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{n!} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{\\ln n}{n^{2}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(1-\\cos\\frac{\\pi}{n}) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{\\sqrt[n]{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(\\sqrt[n]{n}-1) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{n^{2}}{2^{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{[2+(-1)^{n}]^{n}}{2^{2n+1}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}n^{2}e^{-n} \\)
analysis: Root test: Limit is e^{-1} < 1 \\Rightarrow Converges [cite: 59]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{2^{n}n!}{n^{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(\\sqrt{n^{2}+1}-\\sqrt{n^{2}-1}) \\)
analysis: Limit comparison with \\frac{1}{n} gives limit 1. \\Rightarrow Diverges [cite: 62, 63]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(2n-\\sqrt{n^{2}+1}-\\sqrt{n^{2}-1}) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\ln\\frac{n^{2}+1}{n^{2}-1} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(-\\ln\\cos\\frac{\\pi}{n}) \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence of the positive series: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{a^{n}}{(1+a)(1+a^{2})\\cdots(1+a^{n})} \\quad (a>0) \\)
analysis: Ratio test limit: 0 (if a>1), a (if 0<a<1), 1/2 (if a=1). [cite_start]All < 1 implies convergence [cite: 69, 70]

subject: Calculus
question: Prove: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{n\\ln^{q}n} \\) converges if q>1, diverges if q\\le 1.
analysis: Integral Test: \\int_{2}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{x\\ln^{q}x}dx = \\int \\frac{1}{t^q} dt. [cite_start]Converges if q>1, diverges if q<=1. [cite: 73-83]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( -\\frac{1}{2!}+\\frac{1}{3}-\\frac{1}{4!}+\\frac{1}{5}-\\cdots \\)
analysis: S_{2n} = A_n + B_n where A_n (factorial part) converges and B_n (harmonic part) diverges. [cite_start]Sum diverges. [cite: 90-97]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n+x} \\)
analysis: Leibniz test: Converges. Absolute value compares to 1/n (Diverges). [cite_start]\\Rightarrow Conditional Convergence [cite: 105-113]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\\sin\\frac{x}{n} \\)
analysis: Converges by alternating series test. Absolute series compares to |x/n| (Diverges). [cite_start]\\Rightarrow Conditional Convergence [cite: 114-120]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{\\sqrt[n]{n}} \\)

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=2}^{\\infty}(-1)^{n}\\frac{\\ln^{2}n}{n} \\)
analysis: Leibniz test: Converges. Absolute series > 1/n (Diverges). [cite_start]\\Rightarrow Conditional Convergence [cite: 122-125]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{n}}\\cos\\frac{n\\pi}{3} \\)
analysis: S_{6n} grouping shows limit exists (Converges). [cite_start]Absolute series > 1/2\\sqrt{n} (Diverges). [cite: 126-133]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}(-1)^{n+1}\\frac{4^{n}\\sin^{2n}x}{n} \\)
analysis: Root test r = 4sin^2x. If r<1: Absolute Convergence. If r>1: Diverges. [cite_start]If r=1: Conditional Convergence. [cite: 134-143]

subject: Calculus
question: Discuss the convergence: \\( \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\frac{\\sin(n+1)x\\cos(n-1)x}{n^{p}} \\quad (p>1) \\)
analysis: Bounded by 1/n^p. [cite_start]Since p>1, it converges absolutely. [cite: 143-148]
